Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How Urban Adolescents Come to Think of Themselves as Mathematicians

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, the investigator will study how African American and Latino middle and high school students construct their sense of self-identity with and in mathematics and the role that teachers play in helping to shape those self-opinions. This is important because many students, particularly in urban settings, have a poor sense of their own potential in mathematics learning which restricts their attainment in high school and future college studies. If researchers can better understand how students form these opinions of their own abilities, future programs could be designed to improve this situation.

The project has two specific research objectives: (1) to examine how teacher socialization messages in urban math classrooms relate to students' construction of math identities, and (2) to trace how math identities form and change over time, from middle school to the transition into high school. This project will also model how these various identities predict math achievement outcomes. Survey methodology, semi-structured interviews, and cognitive assessments will be employed to address these objectives. For his CAREER award education plan, the investigator proposes to train undergraduate students to mentor urban middle school students around math identity building and self-efficacy issues. Results of this research will be disseminated through peer-reviewed journal articles and conferences and presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project (DRL CAREER Award No #1350814) employed a developmental social-cognitive approach to understand how urban adolescents negotiate their mathematics identities in concert with their racial identities during middle school and across the transition into high school. Since identity is a fluid and multidimensional construct, this study sought to explore the various forces – both internal and external – that shape adolescents’ understandings of themselves as individuals, students, and mathematicians. The project held two research objectives and two educational objectives. The research objectives were 1) to understand how teacher socialization messages in urban mathematics classrooms relate to students’ negotiation of math identities and 2) to track how math identities develop and consolidate over time, beginning in middle school and continuing across the transition into high school. Broadly, we found:

Black and Latinx adolescents often face racial stigma and stereotypes that can undermine the development of their emerging mathematics identities and their perceived value of mathematics. However, teachers have unique opportunities to provide coping-support and cultural validation to help students negotiate their racial identities with successful math identities. Matthews (2018) found that teacher messages about the real-world relevance of math predicted Black and Latinx adolescents’ growth in valuing mathematics over the course of the school year. For many of these adolescents, the developmental maturation of cognitive flexibility also aided the adolescents in being able to process and internalize these teacher messages toward their own identity formation in mathematics. Further, Matthews (under review) found that mathematics teachers who engaged cultural and critical mathematics instruction was associated with Black and Latinx adolescents who negotiated their racial and mathematical identities in ways that led to greater math performance, higher math self-efficacy, more robust resistance motivation, and fewer negative emotions around mathematics. However, beyond instruction alone, mathematics teachers who enacted empathetic caring were found to have students who felt a greater sense of connectedness and belonging in their math classrooms and a greater perceived value of mathematics (Maloney & Matthews, 2020; Matthews, 2019). Finally, the most recent work from this project used latent profile analysis (LPA) to underscore how Black American adolescents negotiate their racial and mathematical identities in concert, particularly when they perceive their racial group to be negatively evaluated by society (Matthews, under review). The findings revealed 1) multiple typologies of racially informed math identities, and 2) that grade level, school environment, and culturally relevant math pedagogy predict the development of and changes in these typologies over time.  Of particular significance in this work was the finding that revealed some Black adolescents resist stigma in both mathematics and society more broadly by cultivating an achievement-oriented math identity for personal and collective liberation, which can be shaped by teachers’ engagement of cultural and critical mathematics pedagogy.

 

The education objectives of this project aimed to provide direct instruction and enrichment for urban youth who participated in the research activities through a weekly mentorship program implemented by trained university undergraduates. Co-developed and directed by the PI (Matthews), this program focused on enhancing the perceived relevance of mathematics, challenging unhealthy self-beliefs, and facilitating character development and communal orientation among urban youth. The education objectives were to 1) support urban middle school students through a mentorship program that provides quality relational support, implements self-development exercises grounded in social intervention research, and provides basic math and social support, all from collegiate mentors. The second goal was to 2) train the undergraduate mentors to implement the 15-week mentorship program.

Both education objectives were satisfied by the THREADS mentorship program, which commenced operations in January 2016 and still functions to this day. Each year for the last five years, undergraduate students were selected to facilitate a weekly mentorship program with 5th-, 6th-, and/or 7th-grade students of color from a large city. The undergraduate mentors participated in weekly seminars to study recent and seminal research related to the psychosocial development of urban youth, which facilitated their development as both mentors and as future educators and community advocates. After the seminar, the undergraduate mentors implemented a series of mentorship sessions that were adapted from empirically effective psychological and educational interventions. The THREADS program has received extensive support and praise from former mentors, school administration, teachers, and the students themselves. Please see https://threadsmentorship.com/ for more information on our logic model, testimonials, and history.
